On Jan 5, 2008 5:08 PM, petar_chervenski <petar_chervenski@...> wrote:
>
>  Well, we all assume that everything started with single-cell
>  organisms like the amoeba and the bacteria.

Actually, cells are enormously complex...it's doubtful that life
started as a well-formed cell. Some hypothesize that the first
replicators were something like free-floating strands of RNA that
operated like templates for molecules exactly like themselves.

>  Besides, there is something that can even break the evolution theory.
>  An example is the bacteria's propeller tail. It is a very complex
>  mechanism composed of many parts depending on each other. How did
>  this evolve? What was that gene appearance? This just cannot evolve
>  gradually, it is a "jump" in evolution. I know that the populations
>  get separated into species within their own niches but the quiestion
>  of how this evolved is not answered yet.

The evolution of the bacterial flagellum is a favorite chestnut of the
creationist (intelligent design) movement, especially Michael Behe.
But explaining its gradual evolution is not problematic. Go wade
through this site if you want a decent explanation:

http://www.talkdesign.org/faqs/flagellum.html

--Derek
